steps: I often manage to complete a task well, even if at first I thought I wouldn’t be able to handle it
I can create the impression that I am more competent than I really am
I feel terrified when someone evaluates my work
When people praise me for my achievements, I worry that I won’t live up to their expectations in the future
Sometimes I think I got this position or my current success just because I happened to be in the right place at the right time
I’m afraid that people who are important to me will find out that I’m not as capable as they think
I tend to remember my failures more than my successes
I rarely complete a project or task as well as I would like to
Sometimes I feel that my success in life or at work is due to some kind of mistake
I find it difficult to accept compliments or praise about my intelligence and achievements
At times I feel that I owe my success to luck
I feel disappointed with what I’ve achieved so far and think I should have accomplished much more
Sometimes I’m afraid that others will discover how much I actually lack in knowledge or skills
I often worry that I might fail at a new task or project, even though I usually do similar things well
When I succeed at something and receive recognition for it, I doubt that I can repeat that success
If I receive a lot of praise and recognition for what I’ve achieved, I tend to downplay the importance of my accomplishments
I often compare my abilities with those of people around me and think they are more intelligent than I am
I often worry that I won’t be able to handle a project or an exam, even when people around me are confident in my abilities
If I’m expecting a promotion or some kind of recognition, I don’t tell others about it until it has definitely happened
I feel bad if I am not “the best” in situations that involve achievement

0.text: People with impostor syndrome often underestimate their abilities and attribute their achievements to external factors such as luck or other people’s help instead of recognising their own skills and effort.
0.fact: Emma Watson, a well-known actor and activist, has spoken openly about feeling like an impostor. Despite her success in film and public work, she has often doubted her abilities and feared that others would discover her “not being good enough”.

1.text: Feeling that you come across as more competent than you believe yourself to be is a hallmark of impostor syndrome. People with this pattern often feel that their success is undeserved and fear being “found out”.
1.fact: According to the American Psychological Association, around 25% of office workers feel less competent than their colleagues believe them to be.

2.text: Fear of having your work evaluated is a common sign of impostor syndrome. People with this experience often worry that their work will turn out to be “not good enough”.
2.fact: Fear of evaluation can lead to procrastination and avoiding tasks that require feedback or review, which in turn reinforces self-doubt and self-criticism.

3.text: Being able to accept praise and acknowledge your achievements is an important step in overcoming impostor syndrome. Psychologists recommend regularly reminding yourself of your successes and learning to accept compliments without arguing with them internally.
3.fact: In surveys of students at highly selective universities, about 60% reported feeling less confident in their abilities after receiving positive grades or praise.

4.text: Recognising your skills and hard work is a key step in reducing impostor feelings. People who regularly review and acknowledge their own successes are less likely to experience strong impostor syndrome.
4.fact: Tina Fey, a well-known comedian and writer, has repeatedly mentioned her impostor feelings. She often thought her success in comedy and television was just luck. In her book “Bossypants”, she shares her doubts and fears, showing that even highly successful people can feel out of place.

5.text: Psychotherapy, especially Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), helps people notice and change their negative thoughts and beliefs. CBT supports a more realistic view of one’s own abilities and achievements.
5.fact: Tom Hanks, a famous actor and two-time Oscar winner, has spoken frankly about his fear of being exposed. He has admitted that he often feels out of place and worries that people will realise he is not as talented as they think.

6.text: People with impostor syndrome often focus on their failures and minimise or ignore their successes. This is linked to cognitive distortions such as a negative mental filter and “discounting the positives”.
6.fact: Michelle Obama, former First Lady of the United States, has talked about her own impostor feelings and tendency to dwell on failures. In her book “Becoming”, she describes how she struggled with the idea that her success was random and undeserved, and how she gradually learned to acknowledge and value her achievements.

7.text: Feeling dissatisfied with your work and constantly striving for something better is common among people with impostor syndrome. They often set unrealistically high standards for themselves, which makes it difficult to feel that a project is “good enough”.
7.fact: Perfectionism can strongly reinforce impostor feelings. People who always strive for the ideal often experience high anxiety and a strong fear of failure, which prevents them from appreciating what they have already accomplished.

8.text: This cognitive distortion is sometimes called the “illusion of randomness”: success is seen as a fluke rather than the result of competence and effort. It is closely linked to low self-esteem and harsh self-criticism.
8.fact: Albert Einstein, one of the most influential scientists in history, spoke at times about feeling like an impostor. Despite his outstanding contributions, he considered many of his successes to be due to luck and believed people overestimated his abilities.

9.text: A harsh inner critic can make it difficult to accept positive feedback. People with impostor syndrome often interpret compliments as exaggerated, insincere or undeserved, which prevents them from integrating positive information about themselves.
9.fact: Surveys suggest that around 60% of women and 40% of men find it hard to accept compliments in professional settings because they feel they have not truly earned them.

10.text: People with impostor syndrome often feel that their success is due to luck or chance rather than their own competence. This can maintain a chronic sense of anxiety and fear of being exposed.
10.fact: External success and recognition do not necessarily make impostor feelings disappear. Even people at the top of their professions can continue to feel like “frauds”.

11.text: Again, difficulties accepting praise are closely tied to impostor syndrome. Compliments can trigger discomfort or embarrassment instead of joy, because they contradict the person’s internal, more critical self-image.
11.fact: Studies show that many professionals tend to brush off praise with phrases like “It was nothing” or “Anyone could have done it”, which reinforces the habit of discounting their own achievements.

12.text: People with impostor syndrome are often genuinely highly capable, but their inner beliefs do not match reality. They underestimate their knowledge and skills, which keeps them in a state of ongoing tension and self-doubt.
12.fact: Practices such as compassionate self-talk and keeping a record of achievements can help reduce the fear of being “found out”. Therapists often encourage clients to regularly note specific examples of their competence.

13.text: Fear of failure with new tasks, even when similar tasks have gone well in the past, is a typical sign of impostor syndrome. This can limit professional growth, because a person may avoid new challenges and opportunities.
13.fact: This fear is often linked to perfectionism and extremely high expectations of oneself. When only a flawless result feels acceptable, any uncertainty about success becomes very threatening.

14.text: Doubting your ability to repeat success, even after recognised achievements, is related to cognitive distortions such as impostor syndrome and the “expert paradox”, where highly competent people see their success as fragile or accidental.
14.fact: This pattern is also connected to the Dunning–Kruger effect: people with high competence tend to underestimate their abilities, whereas less competent people often overestimate theirs. Those with impostor syndrome usually fall into the first group.

15.text: The tendency to downplay your achievements, even in the face of praise and recognition, is an example of the cognitive distortion known as “disqualifying the positive”. People with this pattern ignore or devalue their successes.
15.fact: Psychologists often recommend intentionally acknowledging your accomplishments — for example, by keeping a success journal or talking through achievements with someone you trust — to counteract the habit of dismissing them.

16.text: Constantly comparing yourself with others can lead to a sense of chronic “not enough”, where attention is focused only on your own perceived shortcomings and not on your strengths.
16.fact: People with impostor syndrome often forget that many of those around them also experience self-doubt. Realising that you are not alone in these feelings can reduce the sense of isolation and inadequacy.

17.text: Anxiety before important tasks is often linked to perfectionism and fear of failure. People with impostor syndrome may set the bar so high that almost any outcome feels at risk of being “not good enough”.
17.fact: Research shows that supportive feedback and encouragement from others can significantly reduce anxiety and boost confidence. Developing skills of self-support and mindfulness also helps in coping with impostor feelings.

18.text: Surveys of professionals show that about 55% of respondents delay sharing news about their successes, worrying that things might not work out or that others might react negatively.
18.fact: Sheryl Sandberg, COO of Meta (Facebook) and author of “Lean In”, has admitted that she was often afraid to talk about her achievements. She worried that if she shared them too early, she might not live up to expectations or might face criticism.

19.text: The drive to be “the best” can lead to burnout and chronic stress. People with impostor syndrome often work harder and longer than necessary to meet their own high standards, which can harm their mental and physical health.
19.fact: Serena Williams, one of the most successful tennis players in history, has spoken about her intense need to stay at the top and about impostor-like feelings. Despite her many titles and victories, she has often felt pressure always to perform perfectly and feared not meeting expectations.

normal.text: Your result points to a stable sense of competence and self-confidence. You are not overly inclined to doubt your achievements or constantly compare yourself to others, and you are able to acknowledge your successes openly. Even when you make mistakes, you keep faith in your abilities and continue moving forward. This balanced attitude toward yourself supports your development and gives you a solid inner foundation.
normal.title: Confidence in your own worth

light.text: At times it may be difficult for you to fully accept your achievements or to respond to praise without inner tension. You may sometimes compare yourself to others or wonder whether you really meet expectations. At the same time, you are generally able to return to a more objective view, recognise your efforts and see your strengths. This is a good basis for further strengthening your confidence in yourself.
light.title: Mild signs of impostor syndrome

severe.text: Your result suggests that doubts about your own competence may significantly affect your confidence and your ability to express yourself freely. You may often feel afraid of “not measuring up” or worry that others will notice your weaknesses. This harsh inner critic can make it difficult to fully accept your achievements and tap into your potential. Support, work on self-esteem and developing self-compassion skills can help reduce this pressure.
severe.title: Marked signs of impostor syndrome

extreme.text: Your result points to a strong inner vulnerability around recognising your own achievements. You may often feel that your successes are accidental, while mistakes seem to confirm a lack of competence. This state can be emotionally exhausting and make it hard to feel satisfied with your own path. It is important to remember: you do not have to cope with this alone — seeking support and working with your inner critic can be an important step toward greater confidence and self-acceptance.
extreme.title: Pronounced signs of impostor syndrome

text: Have you ever felt that your success was just a matter of luck and that your achievements were not really deserved?
Impostor syndrome is an emotional state in which it is difficult for a person to recognise their own competence and merits, even when they are obvious to others.
This test can help you assess how strongly this pattern affects your life and become a first step toward a deeper understanding of yourself and your strengths.
